title: OUTRAGE as Hammond plans tax raid on PENSIONS to fill £2billion budget blackhole
text:
Rather than attacking hard pressed pensioners and workers saving for a pension to pay for his own mistake, he should take it from the expanding foreign aid budget Andrew Charalambos 
Ukip pensions spokesman Andrew Charalambos said: “Rather than attacking hard pressed pensioners and workers saving for a pension to pay for his own mistake, he should take it from the expanding foreign aid budget." 
Mr Hammond, whose future as Chancellor is being questioned, U-turned over increasing national insurance contributions (NICs) on “white van man" and other self employed because of a manifesto promise not to raise national insurance, income tax or VAT. 
The 3p NICs increase was meant to fund a new social care package worth £2 billion and now Mr Hammond needs to find the money elsewhere without increasing borrowing. 
He also cannot touch pensioner benefits or reverse the triple lock guarantee on the state pension because they were also protected in the 2015 Conservative manifesto. 
However, it is understood that Mr Hammond is considering going after tax relief on pension contributions. 
According to reports a source close to Mr Hammond said: “That's what is being talked. What else is there? 
“There isn't much else. What else can you do? He's not going to compromise the government's reputation on fiscal integrity and we're not going to be borrowing more. That's very clear." 
Pension relief means that people saving for a private pension get paid back money for every pound based on what level of tax they pay. 
This means that for every £1 basic rate taxpayers put in pensions the government pays 20p back but higher rate taxpayers get 40p and 45p back. GETTY In total Mr Hammond needs to raise £325 million in 2018/19 and £645 million in 2019/20 
Baroness Altmann, a leading pension expert who also served in David Cameron's government, warned that Mr Hammond's predecessor George Osborne had balked at hitting pension tax relief. 
She said: “You have to remember that George Osborne was very nervous about this because it affects core Conservative voters. “It also potentially hits public sector workers so it can cause problems there. 
“So the Chancellor really does need to tread very carefully with this." 
But she also accepted that “he does not have many options" available to him. Find out what the BUDGET means for YOU Wed, March 8, 2017 Budget 2017: Philip Hammond hailed Britain’s booming Brexit economy today as he delivered his first Budget of the year
